newsitem.title: ITALY: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Wednesday December 4.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Wednesday December 4.

text.p: Following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.

* Prime minister Romano Prodi hit back from a European security summit in Lisbon after yet more speculation that a crisis in his government coalition was waiting to happen. "We are going ahead, we don't need any other (government) shape" (all).

* Opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi said he had never talked of the need for a broad coalition government to carry out constitutional reforms after predicting the Prodi coalition would fall next spring (all).

* Magistrates and leftist Pds party leader Massimo D'Alema criticised the chairman of a parliamentary committee, Giovanni Pellegrino, who said magistrates had a "strategic plan to gain political domination" (all).
* A trade-union backed report outlines tax evasion in Italy amounts to 250 trillion lire each year (all).
* The lira hit a peak of 977.65 per mark, the highest level since June 1994 (all).

* The International Monetary Fund (IMF), whose inspectors are due to carry out their traditional year-end visit in Italy in a few weeks, asked for explanations of the government's rescue plan of ailing Banco di Napoli. Rating agency Moody's announced it could downgrade Mediocredito centrale, which engaged itself to submit a formal offer to buy a 60 percent stake in the southern bank (all).

* State industrial holding Iri is ready to merge with Fintecna to speed up the sale of motorway building and management company Autostrade. Autostrade is owned 20 percent by Iri and 66 percent by Fintecna (Sole 24 Ore).
Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
